wikipedia_page.main: Aileen Neilson (born 15 August 1971) is a Scottish wheelchair curler. She is the first woman to skip a wheelchair curling team in either the Paralympic Games (2010) or World Championships (2011).

link_mentions.page: Wheelchair curling at the 2010 Winter Paralympics
response: | Michael McCreadie || Aileen Neilson || Tom Killin || Angie Malone || Jim Sellar || Tom Pendreigh
His partner is former teammate and successor as skip of the British Paralympic rink Aileen Neilson.

link_mentions.page: Great Britain at the 2010 Winter Paralympics
response: Britain’s wheelchair curling team consisted of Michael McCreadie, Angela Malone, Tom Killin, Aileen Neilson and James Sellar. These five athletes, representing Scotland, had finished fifth at the 2009 World Championships. Three of the team, McCreadie, Malone and Killin, were also in the GB team which won the silver medal in the event at the 2006 Turin Games. McCreadie, who was competing in his seventh Paralympics, won two bronze medals for Lawn Bowls in the 1976 Summer Paralympics and Killin was a previous silver medalist in wheelchair fencing at the 1980 Summer Games.

link_mentions.page: Wheelchair curling at the Winter Paralympics
response: | Aileen NeilsonGregor EwanBob McPhersonJim GaultAngie Malone

In 2010 Killin was again part of Great Britain's Paralympic wheelchair curling team. The team, which also featured Michael McCreadie as skip, Angela Malone, Aileen Neilson and James Sellar, had finished fifth at the 2009 World Championships. Britain won three of their nine group games, beating teams from Switzerland, Germany, and Japan. They finished in sixth position, which meant that they did not advance to the medal matches.

link_mentions.page: List of Paralympic medalists in wheelchair curling
response: | Aileen NeilsonGregor EwanBob McPhersonJim GaultAngie Malone

The 2011 World Wheelchair Curling Championship was held in Prague, Czech Republic from February 22 - March 1, 2011. Ten mixed gender teams competed for four playoff spots. In the final, Canada's Jim Armstrong defeated Scotland's Aileen Neilson in the final in 7 ends. Teams also gained qualification points from this event for the 2014 Winter Paralympic Games in Sochi.
